title: Between 9 August 2019 and 8 September 2019, will anti-government protests in Russia result in five or more fatalities?
preds: Not in the interest of the Moscow regime to stir up dissent through fatalities. You don't want to make martyrs out of protesters.  Besides the time period left is small lowering the chances of such an incident.

Five protesters who were arrested and charged with rioting connected to recent anti-government rallies walked free on Tuesday after Russian investigators dropped the charges against them. Separately, two protesters who accepted a plea bargain were given jail sentences in an expedited trial. The Investigative Committee’s decision to drop the charges marks a U-turn in what has largely been seen as a widening crackdown on Russia’s opposition and its supporters. Fourteen people, mostly with no history of political activism, have been charged with rioting, which carries up to eight years in prison. The charges relate to an unauthorized protest on July 27 that was marked by police violence. The protesters, however, weren’t seen attacking the police, and no property damage was reported. The investigators said Tuesday that they “found no criminal activities” in the actions of the five people and dropped the charges against them. The investigators also said that they have asked the court to release two more suspects who have been under house arrest.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-protest-leader-to-face-court/2019/09/03/cacf5cb4-ce2c-11e9-a620-0a91656d7db6_story.html I pity da fool who underestimates the power of Putin!

Misread the closing date for my last forecast. With only a few days to go and given that in recent years the administration reacted brutally, but not with anything coming close to lethal force, this seems almost impossible,.
Evidently, Mr. Putin has been an intelligence officer for a long time and he knows well that increasing civilian fatalities will trigger more protests in his country.
We will never get to know.
Russia is brutal in handling protests. https://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2019/aug/13/riot-police-in-russia-punch-woman-during-protest-for-free-elections-video

Whilst there are clearly troubles in Russia (understatement), it is being reported that police are using tear gas and rubber bullets.
Reports that a couple of people have lost eyes, a lot of police getting injured.  Nothing approaching fatality status just yet.
That's the sort of media they would like to avoid.

I would not put it past the Putin regime to use deadly force on the streets. With that being said its possible a large number might disappear and be tortured to death outside of the public eye along with attempted censorship and social media blackouts during the protest.

The authorities haven't in the past been afraid of the bad international reaction, which would suggest the answer should be yes, but I think the Hong Kong situation may lead them to greater caution than in the past.
Based on previous protests in Russia and their pragmatic mindset
Brutality is common but police death isn’t
Putin will attempt to crack down.
Russia is particular about the image it presents. Security forces heavy handedness could inadvertently lead to 1 fatality which could go unreported or spun as resulting from some other cause.

Things are volatile, and it is always a possibility that protesters will be killed.  But the odds at this point are pretty slim.  The opposition in Russia has already been very much contained.  Killing folks seems a bit much, even for Putin (at this point).
In the global political climate, it would reflect very poorly for a global superpower to kill peaceful protesters. It is highly unlikely that Russia would kill protesters, but not impossible.

Russia is very aware that the world is watching. They will avoid fatalities to avoid negative attention. However, Russia also has a record of disregard for the opinion of the rest of the world and will restrain themselves only so far. I expect a few fatalities perhaps, but not more than five.
Lack of precedent plus Putin and Russian authorities are pretty good at Killing people before they present a serious risk of public problem.
Repression isn’t working like it used to. We will see on August 31st. https://www.economist.com/europe/2019/08/15/protests-in-moscow-show-that-putins-critics-are-getting-stronger
I think Russia is very effective at controlling its populace more subtly than this. If the window was until end of year I might put it at 50%
I believe that there will be retribution toward protesters, but I do not think it will necessarily be disclosed.
While there are a lot of protests, not a lot of fatalities do occur, or at least are reported to the media. Russia is carefull not to use deadly force in plain sight.
Current crowd control measures appear sufficient.
Quite possible but does not seem like a strong probability. IF two are killed then I would expect more to follow as protests escalate.
The Russian goverment will take a lot more preemtive messures with arrests before the protests.

Unlikely in this time frame. Russian security services are heavy handed but they are unlikely to stoke flames by killing anyone and the protestors don't have the numbers to isolate any security officials to kill them. There may be a targeted assassination of a protest leader, as has happened before, but even then this isn't likely, and 5 or more fatalities isn't likely

Since many days: no news about protests in moscow
For the moment: its over
Doesn't appear to be any greater degree of violence protests occuring in Russia than what's previously occurred over last several years.
Russia targets influential personnel rather than mass fatalities. Putin acts very strategically to minimize opposition.
Short time span and little precedent for bloody protests.
The security forces would have to be very inept to want / let this happen.

They want no martyr
The russian oficcial are "slick"

Detentions and arrests are more effective as an example to protestors. They will likely wait things out and let the protests lose steam and support over time. Deaths will be avoided at all costs to prevent escalating protests.
The only caveat is how well The Western media sees, documents and reports such incidents. That number have very likely already perished.

It is ironic that while I agree with @acohen conclusion, I disagree with the logic. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/894324 acohen: “Since the fall of the Soviet Union there haven't been protests where people have died" Respectfully, not quite. Actually, a lot of people died during protests. More than in Moscow during the October Revolution of 1917, which started the bloody Civil War.  In 1993, two years after the USSR dissolution, during so called Constitutional Crisis, "On October 3, demonstrators removed police cordons around the parliament and, urged by their leaders, took over the Mayor's offices and tried to storm the Ostankino television centre. The army, which had initially declared its neutrality, stormed the Supreme Soviet building in the early morning hours of October 4 by Yeltsin's order, and arrested the leaders of the resistance. 
The ten-day conflict became the deadliest single event of street fighting in Moscow's history since the Russian Revolution.[1] According to government estimates, 187 people were killed and 437 wounded." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_crisis acohen: "The modern Russian state, while corrupt, is not brutal" Just imagine - the tanks were firing at the Parliament building right in the center of Moscow. Special forces were firing machine guns at demonstrators (yes, some of them were armed) at Ostankino. "62 people were killed, including Terry Michael Duncan, an American lawyer, who was in Moscow to establish a law firm and was killed while attempting to help the wounded...Two French, one British and one American journalist were killed by sniper fire during the massacre." Let me remind that Putin was hand-picked by Yeltsin (who was the president during the Constitutional crisis) not because Putin has a gentle soul. He brutally suppressed the Chechen bid for independence when tens of thousands died. The only reason that Putin does not use (brutal) force is that he discounts opposition as extremely weak - his ratings are still high and opposition leaders are mostly discredited by the government-controlled media. The moment he perceives them dangerous, it will be blood. Why not - they are already marked as puppets/traitors bought by the US.
And actually, there have been killings - not during protests though - of opposition figures, journalists and alike. Ukraine, with the same roots in the Soviet Union and similar culture, also proves the point - during Maidan (just 5 years ago), more than a hundred people died during protests when the balance of power shifted and was in doubt. To be sure, I chose acohen's post because actually I appreciate his opinion.

If there are any deaths, I don’t think they will be intentional and therefore 5 seems like a high number between now and the 8th. However, given the heavy handed tactics used by police, there remains a chance that it could happen, albeit a low one.
Given the timeframe, the likelihood of that many verified deaths due to anti-gov't protests is very small.

here is a intresting video (radio liberty): ttps://www.facebook.com/rferl/videos/vb.122264309574/2336421303109808/?type=2&theater
after -2:01 Min you see the ight up the Date 20. July and the man with "росгва́рдия" sign on back possible that' s the "russian national guards"  
for more information about this securty force look herer:  https://inmoscowsshadows.wordpress.com/2016/04/05/putins-new-national-guard-what-does-it-say-when-you-need-your-own-personal-army/
thats anti-illegal-protest-specialist
The BIG POINT is:  I found videos with this "Special police" only on 20. July.
after this date the russian officials "think" normal Police is enough?
no "bigger" power necessary?, bigger power with more (no five or more fatalities necessary)?  sombody with other video after 20. July with "russian national guard"?

I can imagine a single accidental fatalities but five suggests either five separate incidents or a mass incident and I don't believe there is sufficient time for this to occurespecially with the current political climate in Moscow
How many deaths so far, this number is not reported so we can get better data.

Opposition leaders continue to be able to draw sizable crowds with 50,000 attending a protest on 8/10 in Moscow. Though the protests have resulted in hundreds of arrests and reports of excessive violence by police, there have been no fatalities. As long as the protests remain peaceful, Moscow will continue to show some restraint as killing unarmed protestors would look very bad ahead of regional elections this fall. It is therefore extremely unlikely that 5 or more fatalities will occur before Sept 8.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/moscow-antigovernment-protest-draws-tens-of-thousands-11565461697
https://www.stratfor.com/article/what-protests-russia-could-mean-kremlin

No new news
Nice to meet you, intressting analysis about police tactics in Moskau (vs Hong Kong) https://meduza.io/en/feature/2019/08/15/moscow-vs-hong-kong

communist party protest on 17.08. possible approved 
communist party call for participation on next weekend
look the video 
https://twitter.com/kprf no-communist opposition protest forbiden "divide and conquer" the enemy of gouverment? tactic instead of power!
Putin is a very shrewd politician and he'll take pro active steps to avoid the situation going out of hand.

no fatalities in the past (lot of sources)
police disciplined (lot of vidos) - beating? yes! but not "enough hate"  for five fatalities On the other hand:  township forbiden protest on sunday 17.8.
(Facebook by local politician Andrej Morew)
illegal protest = more brutality next weekend?
Muhhh Russia.  Protests seem pretty tame so far (protests not riots) and period in question is for short duration.   China/HK much more interesting right now.

The modern Russian state, while corrupt, is not brutal. Since the fall of the Soviet Union there haven't been protests where people have died and this includes large scale demonstrations such as the protests in 2011 (elections), 2014 (anti-war), 2017 (elections), and 2018 (pensions). The protests going on now are local and it seems they will be handled according to the tried and true playbook: massive detentions and media blackouts.  The question would be more interesting if it asked about have a single fatality because five is an absurd number given how past protests have been handled.

..Developing nuclear accident story could possibly add 'fuel' to protests (both sides) if (apparent) mishandling (cover-up?) by authorities persists, and country's inhabitants generally feel misled, unsafe.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/russian-village-near-nuclear-fueled-missile-explosion-to-be-briefly-evacuated/2019/08/13/c5eb04d0-bdc6-11e9-a5c6-1e74f7ec4a93_story.html?

How is the follower of Putin?
The are nervous.
there have been some deaths in past, but it does not seem to tha level now.  Separating a child from parents because they allowed child to attend, suggests this is more adminstrative.
These protests are not really organic.  Outsiders would like to see fatalities, but the Russians figure that.

My forecast is mainly based on the low historical frequency as pointed out by others. Additionally, we have to consider the incentives for Putin. Among others, he wants to avoid a spectacle now more than previously due to the slide in his approval rating.

This weekend a video emerged of a policeman hitting female protester: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fw9hoHJ3vEk
Someone offered 100k rubles ($1.5k) for the name of the policeman and his colleagues were happy to share it
On Monday (today) we know the identity of the guy: https://zona.media/news/2019/08/12/cyplakov
He amended all of his social media accounts, hides from reporters and the police case against him is already open The aim here is to deter future police violence and something tells me it is an effective tool...

Putin wants the continuing will of his people, he wants to be seen as fair and impartial as well as a powerbroker who can get get Russia on its feet !  Putin a former KGB officer, has the support of the remaining members of the soviet political bureau.    The old soviet elite want a strong Russia, not a old barely able country with lack of proper parts and food stuffs. The disqualification of opposition candidates is seen as helpfull support of Putin for a strong Russia.   With differences in opinion that can not be addressed there will be conflict.  With conflict there will be struggle and open fights of opinion.  Fatalities may happen because of election conflict!
Not likely. Arrest perhaps, then quiet executions more probable.

I checked on Wikipedia to see whether there have been fatalities in any of the protests so far and there have not been.  I think Putin uses detention, sometimes in great numbers but not fatalities maybe because a lot of russians support these demonstrations.
Excellent base rate comments by colleagues indicate zero fatalities in previous rounds of protests.  Will change forecast if security forces become much more active.
NB: I think there could be fatalities, but no many.
It's a gimme. Pick any number, Putin will make it haappen...

There well could be 5 or more protestor casualties in Moscow, but the public will never know. This is a real bogus question because it relies on information controlled by the Russian state. I’m surprised it was posted.

The deaths were 0 in the 2017-18 protests. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests

This seems to have never happened since the collapse of the SU. I could only find isolated deadly incidents where protesters have been killed. Current protests seem to be on a similar scale or smaller than the last big ones in 2017/2018 and 2011. This would indicate that the Russian government doesn't have a good reason to kill more than five people. Which makes accidents/unilateral police action the most likely cause. However, I'd expect this to be exceedingly unlikely as well.
No fatalities. Putin cannot afford it.

Wikipedia documented two rounds of large protests in Russia (2012-13 and 2017-18) [1] [2].  While hundreds of arrests were made and there were injuries, there was no fatality from the protests.  While there has killing/murder of journalists and poisoning of opposite political figures (by pro-government forces and, maybe even the secret services) in the past, the police appeared to have enough control not to use too much force, and hence no fatality.  Hope this tendency will continue.  [1]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932013_Russian_protests
[2]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests

Five or more casualties during the time period seems unlikely per recent history of demonstrations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011%E2%80%932013_Russian_protests), and current relatively small (percentage) size of 'determined' opposition. (https://news.sky.com/story/moscow-protests-show-putins-draconian-management-of-democracy-11781406).  
(See also analyses provided by other forecasters, below.)   Suggest that country/city leadership will continue to attempt control mainly through arrests as well as other non-lethal tactics. ..Also don't currently believe that Putin and other leaders want negative attention, condemnation that deaths would bring. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/02/world/europe/putins-moscow-protests.html https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/10/world/europe/opposition-protest-moscow.html
inevitable that some clashes will occur
Lots of folks getting scooped up and put in jail, but so far pretty light on casualties.

No fatalities last time around. Looking at ACLED data and limiting to any kind of protest, there were 955/152760 (0.6%) that had a fatality. For 5 or greater it was a fraction of that ~115. Of the 2324 protests the ACLED lists in Russia, none resulted in a fatality. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests
https://www.acleddata.com/data/

During the last two major rounds of protests (2017-18, 2011-13) despite there being thousands of arrests there were no reported casualties on either the protestors side or the police. The question is asking if 5 will occur in a month, which would be high given there have been 0 in protests over the past 10 years.
It could, but I don’t think any ‘facts’ will be released by government.
